JAPAN 1.title: First-Year Japanese I
JAPAN 1.description: An introduction to modern Japanese. Students will develop basic    communicative skills based on the fundamentals of grammar, vocabulary, and conversational expressions. Emphasis on both oral-  aural proficiency  andwriting-reading skills. Introduction to Hiragana and Katakana   syllabaries, and Kanji.

JAPAN 2.title: First-Year Japanese II
JAPAN 2.prereq_description: Japanese 1 with grade C or better, or equivalent.

JAPAN 3.title: First-Year Japanese III
JAPAN 3.prereq_description: Japanese 2 with grade C or better, or equivalent

JAPAN 4.title: Second-Year Japanese
JAPAN 4.prereq_description: Japanese 3 with grade C or better, or equivalent
JAPAN 4.comments: No credit can be earned if more advanced credit in the language has already been awarded.
JAPAN 4.description: Continuation of Japanese 3. Course emphasizes the further development of both oral-aural proficiency and reading-writing skills with an intensive review of basic grammar as well as an introduction to more advanced grammar, vocabulary, and Kanji.

JAPAN 5.title: Second-Year Japanese
JAPAN 5.prereq_description: Japanese 4 with grade C or better, or equivalent
JAPAN 5.comments: JAPAN W 5 is the online version of JAPAN 5.

JAPAN 6.title: Second-Year Japanese
JAPAN 6.prereq_description: Japanese 5 with grade C or better, or equivalent
JAPAN 6.comments: JAPAN W 6 is the online version of JAPAN 6.

JAPAN 17.title: Imagining the Samurai
JAPAN 17.description: A critical exploration of the image and myth of the samurai, Japan's hereditary warrior class, as constructed in Japanese literature, film, drama and art.

JAPAN 25.title: Violence and the Japanese State
JAPAN 25.comments: Same course as History 25 and Japanese 25.
JAPAN 25.description: Examines historiographically and sociologically the Japanese State's   various engagements in violent acts during war and peace times.

JAPAN 63.title: Sociology of Japan
JAPAN 63.description: Sociological macro- and micro-analysis of Japanese society in the    twentieth century.

JAPAN 70.title: Japan in Film
JAPAN 70.description: Students will screen and then write about films by Japanese directors between 1945 and 1985. Students will learn how to evaluate stylistic components of film narrative. The emphasis will be on viewing the films as pictorial representations (and interpretations) of aspects of Japanese society, political, social, cultural.

JAPAN 73.title: INTRODUCTION TO JAPANESE RELIGION: TEXTS, CONCEPTS, AND REPRESENTATIONS
JAPAN 73.description: A SURVEY OF THE MAIN AUTHORS, THEMES, AND STYLES OF THE JAPANESE RELIGIOUS AND PHILOSOPHICAL TRADITIONS THROUGH READINGS FROM AND ANALYSIS OF SOME  SIGNIFICANT AND INFLUENTIAL ORIGINAL TEXTS IN ENGLISH TRANSLATION.

JAPAN 80.title: Masterpieces of Japanese Literature
JAPAN 80.description: Examines a selection of works from Japanese literature, with the goal of understanding the major genres and their development over time. The  cultural roles of literature, as well as criteria for critical     evaluation, are also addressed.

JAPAN 99.title: Independent Study in Japanese
JAPAN 99.comments: Students must have a cumulative 3.0 for the proceeding 1 quarter(s).   Students must have a minimum 3.0 GPA. Limited to 5 units per quarter and 30 units total in all 98/99/198/199/199AA-ZZ courses combined.
JAPAN 99.description: Introduction to independent research in Japanese.  Topic and content are decided by the supervising Professor in the Department of East Asian   Languages and Cultural Studies.

JAPAN 99RA.title: Independent Research Assistance in Japanese
JAPAN 99RA.comments: Students must have a cumulative 3.0 for the proceeding 1 quarter(s).   Students must have a minimum 3.0 GPA. Limited to 5 units per quarter and 30 units total in all 98/99/198/199/199AA-ZZ courses combined.
JAPAN 99RA.description: Research details are decided by the supervising Professor in the   Department of East Asian Languages and Cultural Studies.

JAPAN 111.title: Japanese Folklore
JAPAN 111.description: Introduction to Japanese folklore and folklore studies.  Concepts, categories, and methodologies of folklore studies will be applied to the narrative, life cycle, and material forms of Japanese folklore.  Course also examines motives and aims of Japanese folklorists over time.

JAPAN 112.title: Survey of Modern Japanese Literature
JAPAN 112.description: A survey of Japanese literature after contact with the West, from 1868 to the present. Readings, lectures, and discussions in English.

JAPAN 115.title: Topics in Twentieth-Century Japanese
JAPAN 115.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units.
JAPAN 115.description: Topics to be considered will include: the Japanese novelist as intellectual and social critic; representations of the "self" and similarities and differences between the shosetsu and the western novel; and Japanese literature in and outside Japan.

JAPAN 118.title: On the Road: Japanese Travel Accounts
JAPAN 118.prereq_description: upper division standing or instructor approval
JAPAN 118.description: Travel is an important subject in Japanese literature, where the experiences and feelings of travel have found expression in poetry, journals, memoirs, historical narratives, fiction and drama. We will follow literary itineraries and learn the conventions of writings about travel.

JAPAN 120A.title: Third-Year Japanese I
JAPAN 120A.prereq_description: Japanese 6 with grade C or better, or equivalent
JAPAN 120A.comments: JAPANW 120A is the online version of JAPAN 120A.
JAPAN 120A.description: Develops an intermediate to advanced level of aural-oral skills to carry on conversations on diverse topics with linguistic accuracy and cultural appropriateness, reading skills to comprehend authentic materials, and writing skills with grammatical accuracy and an increasing number of Kanji.

JAPAN 120B.title: Third-Year Japanese II
JAPAN 120B.prereq_description: Japanese 120A with grade C or better, or equivalent
JAPAN 120B.comments: JAPANW 120B is the online version of JAPAN 120B.

JAPAN 120C.title: Third-Year Japanese III
JAPAN 120C.prereq_description: Japanese 120B with grade C or better, or equivalent.
JAPAN 120C.comments: JAPANW 120C is the online version of JAPAN 120C.

JAPAN 125.title: Intermediate Japanese Reading
JAPAN 125.description: Designed to develop skills in reading through translation for students who are studying third-year level Japanese.

JAPAN 134F.title: Arts of Japan
JAPAN 134F.description: Native traditions and foreign influences in the development of Japanese architecture, sculpture, painting, and minor arts.

JAPAN 134G.title: Japanese Painting
JAPAN 134G.description: The changing and entwined traditions of Japanese painting: those rooted in native concepts and practices and those derived from the Asian continent or Euro-America.

JAPAN 134H.title: Ukiyo-e: Pictures of the Floating World
JAPAN 134H.description: Japanese paintings and woodblock prints of the sixteenth through twentieth centuries, with emphasis on issues of genre and format.

JAPAN 134I.description: Exploration of a wide array of Japanese modern and contemporary visual culture in Japan. Emphasis on cultural cross-pollination and global interchange amidst shifting media environments. Topics may vary by year.

JAPAN 134J.title: Understanding Manga
JAPAN 134J.description: An introduction to the development of Manga (Japanese comics) in relation to other world-wide graphic narrative traditions, with special emphasis on visual analysis and historical context.

JAPAN 135AA.title: Special Topics in Japanese Art
JAPAN 135AA.description: Special topics in Japanese Art. Varying topics.

JAPAN 136.title: Early Modern Japanese Literature
JAPAN 136.description: A survey (in English translation) of Japanese fiction, poetry, and drama from the early modern period, or approximately 1600 to 1868. Topics include popular fiction, supernatural tales, travel literature, haikai and haiku, and puppet theater and kabuki.

JAPAN 137.title: Japanese Humor
JAPAN 137.description: An examination of humor and the comic tradition in Japanese culture and literature from earliest times through the present. Topics include comic fiction and poetry, parody and satire, comic storytelling and jokes, standup and slapstick, and TV variety shows.

JAPAN 138.title: Japanese Diasporas
JAPAN 138.description: This course explores the diverse people of Japanese descent in North America, Latin America, and Asia in the modern and contemporary periods. Students investigate how movements shape identities by analyzing a multicultural array of sources including books, articles, and movies.

JAPAN 139.title: Critical Theory Through Anime and Manga
JAPAN 139.description: This course teaches critical theories by combining academic texts by scholars and popular culture products such as anime and manga. The topics include power, hegemony, agency, ritual, magic, hybridity, among others.

JAPAN 140.title: Curiosity and Spectacle in Early Modern Japan
JAPAN 140.prereq_description: Upper division standing or instructor approval
JAPAN 140.description: Cultural and intellectual movements of early modern (Edo) Japan explored through the themes of curiosity and spectacle. Travel, material culture, print media, popular fiction and theater, sideshows and street performers, natural history, the supernatural, the study of foreign cultures and of the past.

JAPAN 144.title: Advanced Japanese Readings I
JAPAN 144.comments: Not open for students who have a Japanese high school education.
JAPAN 144.description: Designed to further develop skills in reading by focusing on analysis of Japanese sentence structure.

JAPAN 145.title: Advanced Japanese Readings II
JAPAN 145.description: Introduces advanced students to selected prose and poetry from post-World War II period.

JAPAN 146.title: Advanced Japanese Readings III
JAPAN 146.description: A selection of texts, including both fiction and non-  fiction, by representative authors from the Meiji period to the present.

JAPAN 149.title: Traditional Japanese Theater
JAPAN 149.description: The major forms of traditional Japanese theater examined through their distinctive features, the ways in which they relate to one another, and the ways in which they connect to broader aspects of Japanese culture. Frequent use of audio-visual materials.

JAPAN 150.title: Globalizing Japan: Culture and Society
JAPAN 150.description: Examines youth culture, sex and gender, terrorism, migration,      race/ethnicity, employment, and consumption patterns to understand the contours of a changing Japan.  Investigates the tension between    preserving "traditional values" and yielding to the influence of   globalization.

JAPAN 153.title: Death, Love & Money in Modern Japan
JAPAN 153.description: How does capitalism remake intimacy and love? How does kinship shape the experiences of aging and death? What is relationship between gender and economy? Students explore these key questions by examining theoretical texts, movies, anime, and manga, among others.

JAPAN 156.title: The Cultural Roots of the Japanese Horror Film
JAPAN 156.prereq_description: Upper division standing or instructor approval
JAPAN 156.description: From classical tales of noblemen and warriors to ghost dramas of medieval and early modern Japan, we will explore premodern creative expression concerning ghosts and their modern appearances in horror films and anime. Texts, images, and film will be used.

JAPAN 159.title: Japanese Cinema
JAPAN 159.comments: Same course as Film and Media Studies 120.
JAPAN 159.description: An introductory scrutiny of major Japanese directors: Mizoguchi, Ozu, Oshima, and Kurosawa. Close attention to their film composition, choices ofsubject and character, their ideas of the cinematic, and the relationship of cinema to Japanese culture and society.

JAPAN 159A.title: Postwar Japanese Cinema (1945-1985)
JAPAN 159A.prereq_description: upper division standing or instructor approval
JAPAN 159A.description: An introductory scrutiny of major Japanese directors: Mizoguchi, Ozu, Oshima, and Kurusawa. Close attention to their film composition, choices of subject and character, their ideas of the cinematic, and the relationship of cinema to Japanese culture and society (1945-1985).

JAPAN 160.title: Topics in Japanese Culture
JAPAN 160.description: Exploration of selected themes that have persisted in Japanese culture to the present.

JAPAN 161.title: Ethnic and Social Diversity in Japan
JAPAN 161.description: Examines how difference is conceptualized and camouflaged in Japan despite an ideology of ethnic homogeneity. Considers the history and development of, and contemporary politics within internal and external minority communities and their diasporas across Japan.

JAPAN 162.title: Representations of Sexuality in Modern Japan
JAPAN 162.comments: Same course as History 188S and Anthropology 176.
JAPAN 162.description: This course examines the main ideologies guiding the establishment of various representations of sexuality from prewar scientific writings to contemporary popular culture.

JAPAN 164.title: Modernity and the Masses of Taisho Japan
JAPAN 164.prereq_description: History 80 or 87 or Upper Division Standing
JAPAN 164.description: Examines the beginnings of a modern mass culture in early twentieth-   century Japan. Central topics are political and social movements, the  new woman and the modern girl, westernization, new media and censorship, modernism and nationalism.

JAPAN 165.title: Popular Culture in Japan
JAPAN 165.description: Examines popular culture in present-day Japan: advertising, music, fashion, television, animation, comics, sports. Integrates visual and acoustic material.

JAPAN 167A.title: Religion in Japanese Culture
JAPAN 167A.prereq_description: Upper division standing or instructor approval
JAPAN 167A.description: A historical analysis of the major components of the classical and medieval religious systems of Japan, through investigation of texts, rituals, and institutions.

JAPAN 168.title: The Films of Akira Kurosawa
JAPAN 168.description: An in-depth study of the films of Akira Kurosawa.  There is a required film viewing session as well.

JAPAN 169.title: Seminar in Traditional Japanese Drama
JAPAN 169.description: In-depth examinations of specific selected topics in traditional Japanese drama. Knowledge of Japanese preferred for readings and research for term papers.

JAPAN 172.title: Music in Modern Japan
JAPAN 172.description: This course explores music and culture in modern Japan. What kind of society do we hear in its diverse mix of sounds and musical practices? We explore this question through traditional genres, national politics, and transnational exchanges of popular media.

JAPAN 175B.title: Shinto Texts through the Ages
JAPAN 175B.description: This course explores the diversity of the Shinto tradition through an  analysis of representative original texts in English translation ranging from ancient mythology (Kojiki, Nihon shoki, and Fudoki) and medieval  syncretic discourses, to modern forms of Shinto nationalism.

JAPAN 180AAZZ.title: Special Topics in Japanese Studies
JAPAN 180AAZZ.comments: Misc:  May be repeated for credit providing letter designations are    different.
JAPAN 180AAZZ.description: Special topics in Japanese Studies. Course content varies.

JAPAN 183.title: Readings in Premodern through Meiji Japanese Texts
JAPAN 183.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units. Not open for credit to students who have completed Japanese 101C.
JAPAN 183.description: Selected readings in medieval, early modern, and Meiji texts.

JAPAN 186RW.title: Seminar in Japanese Art
JAPAN 186RW.description: Studies in Japanese art. Topics vary, but emphasis is usually on the various relationships to global movements. Requires weekly readings, discussion, frequent presentations, and the writing of a well-developed research paper.

JAPAN 197.title: Senior Honors Project
JAPAN 197.prereq_description: Open to senior majors only; consent of instructor.
JAPAN 197.comments: Student must have a 3.0 overall grade-point average and a 3.5 in the major.
JAPAN 197.description: An independent study course (one to three quarters) directed by a faculty  member with a carefully chosen topic and bibliography which will result in a documented project or a senior thesis.

JAPAN 198.title: Readings in Japanese
JAPAN 198.prereq_description: Upper-division standing; completion of 2 upper-division courses in Japaneseconsent of instructor.
JAPAN 198.comments: Students must have a 3.0 GPA for the preceding 3 quarters and are limited  limited to 5 units per quarter and 30 units total in all       98/99/198/199/199AA-ZZ courses combined.  May be repeated up to    12 units.
JAPAN 198.description: Guided reading in Japanese on a subject not covered in the regularly   offered courses.

JAPAN 199.title: Independent Studies in Japanese
JAPAN 199.prereq_description: Upper-division standing; completion of 2 upper-division courses in
JAPAN 199.comments: Students must have a minimum 3.0 GPA for the preceding 3 quarters and  are limited to 5 units per quarter and 30 units total in all     98/99/198/199/199AA-ZZ courses combined.

JAPAN 199RA.title: Independent Research Assistance
JAPAN 199RA.prereq_description: Completion of at least 2 upper-division courses in Japanese studies or EastAsian Cultural Studies; consent of instructor and department.
JAPAN 199RA.comments: Students must have a minimum 3.0 GPA for the 3 preceeding quarters and are limited to 30 units total in all 98/99/198/199/199AA-ZZ courses    combined.

JAPAN 201.title: Readings in Selected Texts
JAPAN 201.prereq_description: Ability to read japanese at graduate level; consent of instructor. Normallygraduate status is required.
JAPAN 201.description: Course will center on readings of japanese texts type and period to depend on needs of students and wishes of instructor. Research methods to be  taught as appropriate.

JAPAN 211.title: Bibliography and Research Methodology
JAPAN 211.description: Introduction to bibliographies, reference works, and methodologies of  research in japanese studies.

JAPAN 226.title: Japan Modern
JAPAN 226.description: Examines Japanese modernity from the mid-nineteenth century to today and analyzes theoretical and methodological approaches to the study of modern  Japanese history and society.

JAPAN 236.title: Transnational Japanese Studies
JAPAN 236.description: The broad goal of this seminar is to teach graduate students how to utilize theory to produce scholarly knowledge. Specifically, it introduces theories pertinent to the study of diaspora, globalization, and transnationalism with a focus on empirical research about Japan.

JAPAN 237.title: Anthropology of Japan
JAPAN 237.description: This course focuses on the history, methods, theories, and politics pertaining to the anthropological study of Japan. It primarily covers the postwar academic texts in English, and occasionally engages sources in Japanese, in alternative formats, and/or from earlier historical periods.

JAPAN 240.title: Curiosity and Spectacle in Early Modern Japan
JAPAN 240.description: Cultural and intellectual movements of early modern (Edo) Japan explored through the themes of curiosity and spectacle. Travel, material culture, print media, popular fiction and theater, sideshows and street performers, natural history, the supernatural, the study of foreign cultures and of the past. Graduate students are assigned additional readings and are expected to submit a longer final research paper.

JAPAN 258.title: True to Life:  The "Natural" Novels of Natsume Soseki and Henry James
JAPAN 258.comments: Concurrent with JAPAN 158.  Graduate students will be assigned additional reading, primary and secondary sources, and longer papers.  Grad students in Japanese studies will be expected to do some of the Soseki readings in the original Japanese.
JAPAN 258.description: Close reading and succinct analysis of works by Natsume Soseki and Henry James.  Class discussion will be propelled by students' brief (500 words) "impressions" of a scene or moment minutely observed.  Critical focus: discerning respective approaches to story-telling as a means of revealing character.

JAPAN 261.title: Graduate Seminar in Shinto Studies
JAPAN 261.description: This seminar addresses various issues in Shinto studies, including the   history of Shinto, Western perceptions of Shinto, Shinto art and theories  of the representation of the sacred, and features of Shinto Nativism.

JAPAN 262.title: Representations of Sexuality in Modern Japan
JAPAN 262.comments:
Concurrently offered with Japan 162. Graduate students have a separate discussion hour with the instructor every other week and write 2 10-page papers. Use of Japanese-language materials required.
Repeat Comments: Topics vary; may be repeated for credit.
JAPAN 262.description: The main ideologies guiding the establishment of various representations of sexuality from pre-war scientific writings to contemporary popular culture.

JAPAN 263.title: Modernity and the Masses of Taisho Japan
JAPAN 263.comments:
Concurrently offered with Japan 164. Graduate students have a separate discussion hour with the instructor every other week and write 2 10-page papers. Use of Japanese-language materials required.
Repeat Comments: Topics vary; may be repeated for credit.
JAPAN 263.description: Examines the beginnings of a modern mass culture in early twentieth- century Japan. Central topics are political and social movements, the new woman and the modern girl, westernization, new media and censorship, modernism and nationalism.

JAPAN 264.title: Problems in the Study of Japanese Religions
JAPAN 264.description: This seminar addresses little-studied topics in the history of Japanese religions with particular  attention to their cultural contexts and methodological issues they raise. This seminar involves  close reading of primary and secondary sources in Japanese.

JAPAN 265.title: Popular Culture in Japan
JAPAN 265.comments:
Concurrently offered with JAPAN 165. Graduate students have a separate discussion hour with the instructor every other week and write 2 10-page papers. Use of Japanese-language materials required.
Repeat Comments: Topics vary; may be repeated for credit.
JAPAN 265.description: Examines popular culture in present-day Japan: advertising, music, fashion, television, animation, comics, sports. Integrates visual and acoustic material.

JAPAN 269.title: Seminar in Traditional Japanese Drama
JAPAN 269.description: In-depth examinations of specific selected topics in traditional japanese drama. Knowledge of japanese required for readings and research for term papers.

JAPAN 275A.title: Shinto: Concepts and Practices in History
JAPAN 275A.comments: Concurrent with JAPAN 175A.  Graduate students will have additional readings specified in the syllabus and an additional research paper.
JAPAN 275A.description: Course presents the variety of religious and cultural phenomena associated with Shinto in Japan through a survey of doctrinal developments throughout history, description of practices, and considerations on the relationship between Shinto and other religions and intellectual systems such as Buddhism, Daoism, Confucianism, and Christianity.

JAPAN 275B.title: Shinto Texts through the Ages
JAPAN 275B.comments: Concurrent with JAPAN 175B.  Graduate students will have additional readings specified in the syllabus and an additional research paper.
JAPAN 275B.description: This course explores the diversity of the Shinto tradition through an analysis of representative original texts in English translation ranging from ancient mythology (Kojiki, Nihon shoki, and Fudoki) and medieval syncretic discourses, to modern forms of Shinto nationalism.

JAPAN 276.title: Advanced Readings in Japanese Texts
JAPAN 276.prereq_description: Japan 144 and 145 or prior approval of instructor
JAPAN 276.description: Readings in Japanese texts on religion (Buddhism and Shinto) and   intellectual history. The course focuses on an accurate understanding of linguistic representation of concepts and stylistic nuances in the   fields of Japanese religious and cultural history.

JAPAN 282B.title: Seminar: Topics of Japanese Art
JAPAN 282B.description: Studies in Japanese art in a comparative context.  Topics vary, but emphasis is usually on the various relationships to global movements.  Requires weekly readings, discussion, frequent presentations, and the writing of a well-developed research paper.

JAPAN 283.title: Special Readings in Prewar Japanese Texts
JAPAN 283.description: Reviews Bungo, followed by readings in the classical, medieval, early modern, and Meiji texts.

JAPAN 287.title: Readings with Japanese Scholars
JAPAN 287.comments: Misc: May be repeated for credit.
JAPAN 287.description: A reading and discussion seminar in Japanese led by a visiting scholar   from Japan. Will introduce Japanese scholarship on a specific chosen   theme.

JAPAN 287J.title: Reinventing "Japan" Colloquium
JAPAN 287J.description: This year-long interdisciplinary colloquium brings together graduate   students who study Japanese history and culture. It introduces current scholarship on Japan via readings, discussions and presentations by  visiting scholars, UCSB scholars and graduate students. The colloquium meets bi-  weekly. Students will prepare readings for discussion, write  on seminar-length paper and present their paper to the colloquium once during the year.

JAPAN 292AAZZ.title: Special Topics
JAPAN 292AAZZ.description: Seminar in special areas of interest in Japanese cultural studies.   Specific course titles and topics to be announced by the department each quarter offered.  Course content will vary.

JAPAN 501.title: Apprentice Teaching
JAPAN 501.prereq_description: Graduate standing and consent of instructor. Employment in this department teaching assistant or linguistic informant.
JAPAN 501.comments: These units do not count toward the graduate degree.
JAPAN 501.description: This course consists of supervised teaching practice in japanese language.

JAPAN 596.title: Directed Reading and Research
JAPAN 596.comments: Letter grade; minimum of two units per quarter.
JAPAN 596.description: Individual tutorial. A written proposal for each tutorial must be approved by department chair and filed with graduate division.

JAPAN 597.title: Preparation for Comprehensive Examinations
JAPAN 597.comments: No unit credit allowed toward degree.
JAPAN 597.description: Study for master's comprehensive examinations and Ph.D examinations.

JAPAN 598.title: Master's Thesis Research and Preparation
JAPAN 598.description: For research underlying the thesis writing the thesis. Instructor should bethe chair of the student's thesis committee.
